settings.description: Enables near real-time token revocation when user accounts are disabled or deleted. CAE reduces the standard token lifetime from 1 hour to minutes, ensuring terminated users lose access almost immediately upon account disablement.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. CAE is automatically enabled for Azure AD Premium P1/P2 tenants
2. Ensure applications support CAE (Microsoft 365 apps do by default)
3. Sign in to Microsoft Entra admin center
4. Navigate to Protection > Conditional Access > Policies
5. Verify existing policies use 'All cloud apps' to enable CAE
6. CAE automatically evaluates critical events:
   - User account disabled/deleted
   - Password changed
   - High-risk users detected
   - User removed from location/group
7. No additional configuration needed; CAE works with existing CA policies

controlMappings.mappingRationale: CAE enforces near real-time session termination when user accounts are disabled, directly addressing the control's requirement to 'disable system access within organization-defined time period' upon termination. Standard access tokens expire in 1 hour, but CAE reduces this to minutes by continuously evaluating critical events including account disablement.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Disable system access within organization-defined time period when employment is terminated

settings.description: Enforces reauthentication every 1 hour for all users, ensuring that disabled accounts cannot maintain active sessions beyond this period. When combined with account disablement, this guarantees session termination within the defined timeframe.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Sign in to Microsoft Entra admin center as Conditional Access Administrator
2. Navigate to Protection > Conditional Access > Policies
3. Create new policy: 'Session Timeout - 1 Hour'
4. Under Assignments > Users: Select 'All users' (exclude break-glass accounts)
5. Under Assignments > Cloud apps: Select 'All cloud apps'
6. Under Access controls > Session:
   - Click 'Sign-in frequency'
   - Set to '1 hour'
   - Enable 'Sign-in frequency'
7. Set 'Enable policy' to 'On' and click Create
8. Note: Use shorter intervals (e.g., 30 minutes) for highly sensitive environments

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Sign-in frequency controls enforce automatic session termination at defined intervals, directly implementing the control's requirement to 'terminate user sessions' upon termination or transfer. By requiring reauthentication every hour, disabled accounts will lose access within this timeframe even if tokens were issued before disablement.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Disable system access within organization-defined time period; Automatically terminate user sessions

settings.description: Configures recurring access reviews for privileged roles to identify and remove unnecessary role assignments after personnel transfers. Ensures role assignments are reviewed and modified when individuals change positions.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Sign in to Microsoft Entra admin center as Privileged Role Administrator
2. Navigate to Identity Governance > Privileged Identity Management
3. Select 'Azure AD Roles' under Manage
4. Select 'Access reviews' and click 'New'
5. Configure review:
   - Select all privileged roles
   - Set recurrence to 'Quarterly'
   - Select reviewers (managers or role owners)
   - Enable 'Auto apply results to resource'
   - Set 'If reviewers don't respond' to 'Remove access'
   - Enable 'Show recommendations' for inactive users
6. Click 'Start' to create recurring review

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Access reviews enforce the control's requirement to 'review and confirm ongoing operational need for current logical access authorizations' when individuals are reassigned or transferred. Quarterly reviews ensure that role assignments are evaluated and modified to correspond with changes in operational need, preventing privilege accumulation during transfers.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Review and confirm the ongoing operational need for current logical access authorizations; Modify access authorization to correspond with any changes in operational need when reassigned or transferred

settings.description: Enforces time-limited privileged role assignments with JIT activation, ensuring that privileged access automatically expires. When personnel are terminated or transferred, their pending activations are automatically revoked, and no new activations can be requested from disabled accounts.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Sign in to Microsoft Entra admin center as Privileged Role Administrator
2. Navigate to Identity Governance > Privileged Identity Management
3. Select 'Azure AD Roles' under Manage
4. Select 'Settings' and choose a privileged role (e.g., Global Administrator)
5. Click 'Edit' and configure:
   - Activation maximum duration: 8 hours (or less)
   - Require approval to activate: Enabled
   - Require justification on activation: Enabled
   - Require ticket information on activation: Optional
6. Under 'Assignment':
   - Allow permanent active assignment: Disabled
   - Allow permanent eligible assignment: Disabled
   - Expire eligible assignments after: 180 days maximum
7. Click 'Update' and repeat for all privileged roles

controlMappings.mappingRationale: PIM with JIT access enforces time-limited privileged role assignments that automatically expire, addressing the control's requirement to 'terminate or revoke authenticators and credentials' upon termination or transfer. When an account is disabled, all active role assignments expire at the maximum duration (typically 8 hours), and eligible assignments can be immediately removed, ensuring rapid credential revocation for privileged access.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Terminate or revoke authenticators and credentials associated with the individual when employment is terminated; Modify access authorization when reassigned or transferred

settings.description: Conditional Access policies automatically block disabled accounts from authenticating. When an account is disabled in Azure AD, all Conditional Access policies that target 'All users' will deny access, ensuring immediate enforcement of account termination.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Sign in to Microsoft Entra admin center as Conditional Access Administrator
2. Navigate to Protection > Conditional Access > Policies
3. Verify existing baseline policies target 'All users'
4. Disabled accounts are automatically blocked by Azure AD authentication
5. Best practice: Create dedicated policy 'Block - Disabled Accounts':
   - Users: All users (exclude break-glass accounts)
   - Cloud apps: All cloud apps
   - Conditions: (none needed - Azure AD blocks disabled accounts)
   - Grant: Block access
6. This is implicit behavior but can be explicitly documented
7. Test: Disable a test account and verify authentication fails immediately

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Azure AD inherently blocks disabled accounts from authenticating, directly enforcing the control's requirement to 'disable system access' upon termination. When combined with Conditional Access policies targeting 'All users' and CAE, this ensures that disabled accounts cannot obtain new tokens and existing tokens are rapidly invalidated, achieving immediate access termination.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Disable system access within organization-defined time period when employment is terminated

settings.displayName: Automatic Device Wipe on Account Deletion
settings.description: Automatically wipes corporate data from managed devices when user accounts are deleted, ensuring that company data is removed from devices and preventing unauthorized access to cached information. This retrieves organizational property by removing corporate data.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Sign in to Microsoft Intune admin center
2. Navigate to Devices > Compliance policies > Policies
3. Create new compliance policy for each platform (Windows, iOS, Android)
4. Configure compliance settings (device health, encryption, etc.)
5. Under 'Actions for noncompliance':
   - Add action: 'Retire the noncompliant device'
   - Schedule: Immediately after noncompliance
6. When user account is deleted:
   - Device automatically becomes noncompliant
   - Intune issues retire command
   - Corporate data is wiped from device
7. For BYOD: Use 'Selective wipe' to remove only company data
8. For Corporate devices: Use 'Full wipe' to factory reset

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Automatic device wipe upon account deletion directly implements the control's requirement to 'retrieve security-related system property' when employment is terminated. Intune's retire/wipe capabilities ensure that company data, authentication tokens, certificates, and other organizational property are removed from devices, preventing terminated employees from accessing cached information or maintaining device-based access.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Retrieve security-related system property (hardware authentication tokens, system administration technical manuals, keys, identification cards, building passes) when employment is terminated

controlNote: These settings enforce technical controls for personnel termination and transfer. They work together to: (1) Disable access within minutes via CAE, (2) Terminate sessions within defined periods via sign-in frequency, (3) Revoke credentials through account disablement and PIM expiration, (4) Remove device-based access via Intune wipe, and (5) Review and modify role assignments via Access Reviews. Organizations should define the 'organization-defined time period' for access disablement (recommended: immediate to 1 hour).
cisReferences: CIS Microsoft 365 Foundations Benchmark v2.0.0 - 5.1.2 (L1) Ensure 'Access reviews' for high privileged Azure AD roles are configured
CIS Microsoft 365 Foundations Benchmark v2.0.0 - 1.1.15 (L2) Ensure 'Privileged Identity Management' is used to manage roles
